title: 104_hr3665
content: The "Census of Agriculture Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. The authority to conduct the Census of Agriculture is transferred to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to conduct a census of agriculture every five years, starting in 1998. The data collected in each census relates to the previous year. Failure to answer census questions truthfully may result in penalties under the United States Code. The census conducted by the Secretary of Agriculture every five years collects data from each State, the District of Columbia, and other areas under U.S. jurisdiction. The Secretary of Commerce can provide information collected under title 13, United States Code, to the Secretary of Agriculture upon request. The Secretary of Commerce may provide information collected under title 13, United States Code to the Secretary of Agriculture upon request for census or survey purposes. The Secretary of Agriculture can also provide information collected in a census to the Secretary of Commerce for statistical purposes only. Rules and regulations for this process can be prescribed by the respective Secretaries. Effective October 1, 1998, rules and regulations for sharing information between the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Agriculture can be prescribed by each respective Secretary. This includes repealing section 142 of title 13, United States Code, and making amendments to section 343(a)(11)(F) of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO CONFIDENTIALITY OF INFORMATION. The text discusses the confidentiality of information provided to the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Commerce, with amendments to relevant sections of the United States Code and the Food Security Act of 1985. Confidential information provided under specific statutes is treated as confidential for purposes of relevant sections of the United States Code. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on July 22, 1996.
